title: Biosecurity Volunteering Hunt
oneLiner: Search for live project or volunteering needs on the central EA opportunties board.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants to contribute time but isn't ready for a full job; Candidate wants to find a 'real' project.
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is looking for reading material only.
firstSmallStep: Search 'Biosecurity' on the board and bookmark 3 potential volunteer roles.
nextStep: Apply to the one that fits your skills best.

title: 80,000 Hours — AI safety researcher career review
oneLiner: A canonical EA-style 'should I do this?' overview, with concrete role shapes and realities.
whenToSuggest: Candidate prefers reading; Candidate wants reality-checks on what the work looks like
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is only looking for a quick interest test (use Robert Miles instead)

goodFitIf: Wants reality-checks on what the work looks like
Interested in understanding role shapes and career paths

firstSmallStep: Skim sections: 'what the work involves' + 'who is a good fit' + write 3 bullets: 'what matches me / what doesn't.'
nextStep: Identify which specific role shape from the review appeals most and research orgs doing that work.

title: 80,000 Hours Job Board
oneLiner: A high-signal job board with many EA-aligned roles; good for building intuition and spotting real orgs/roles.
whenToSuggest: Candidate is ready to make roles concrete or is motivated by seeing real openings; Candidate wants a practical bridge from interest to action
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is very early and gets overwhelmed by job posts (use Experiment A first)

goodFitIf: Wants a practical bridge from interest to action

firstSmallStep: Do the 10–25 min scan: collect 8–12 roles → label role-types → circle 3 roles + 2 repeating skill gaps.
nextStep: Pick one skill gap to start addressing and find resources to build that skill.

title: AGI Safety Fundamentals (AISF)
oneLiner: An 8-week reading-group-style on-ramp used widely in the community: concepts, discussion, and a project component.
whenToSuggest: Candidate is interested and wants deeper understanding + community discussion; Candidate benefits from external structure/accountability
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate has no bandwidth for weekly participation (use Experiment A instead)
firstSmallStep: Read the curriculum/application page and see if week 1–2 feels exciting (not intimidating).
nextStep: Apply for the next cohort if timing works, or join the self-paced version.

title: AISafety.com Jobs
oneLiner: AI-safety-specific curated jobs list; great for quickly seeing the org ecosystem.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants 'AI safety only' without sifting broader EA jobs; Candidate wants to learn org landscape quickly
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is not at job-search stage and would spiral into comparison

goodFitIf: Wants AI safety only without broader EA jobs
Wants to learn org landscape quickly

firstSmallStep: Same scan method: 8–12 roles → 3 interesting roles → 2 repeating skill gaps.
nextStep: Research 2–3 orgs from your list to understand their work and culture.

title: BlueDot Impact — AI courses (AI Safety / AI Governance tracks)
oneLiner: Cohort-based courses that help people understand the field and meet peers; good default 'structured exposure.'
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants structured learning + peers; not ready for a research fellowship yet; Candidate leans governance/policy OR wants a 'less technical' entry option
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is explicitly seeking a mentored project output now (use SPAR)

goodFitIf: Not ready for a research fellowship yet
Leans governance/policy or wants less technical entry

firstSmallStep: Pick one track (technical safety vs governance) and check cohort timing vs bandwidth.
nextStep: Apply for the next cohort that fits your schedule.

title: DeepMind — AGI Safety Course (YouTube playlist)
oneLiner: A short, structured intro from DeepMind; good for people who prefer a 'course vibe' over an explainer video.
whenToSuggest: Candidate likes structured learning and wants an intro under ~1 hour; Candidate is skeptical and prefers institutional framing
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate wants the EA community's strategy framing (use 80k reading alt instead)

goodFitIf: Wants a quick intro under ~1 hour

firstSmallStep: Watch the first chunk and note: 'which track feels more like me: technical vs governance/policy?'
nextStep: Based on which track felt more interesting, explore resources deeper in that direction.

title: EA Opportunities Board
oneLiner: Broader than jobs: fellowships, programs, events, volunteering—useful to find 'entry ramps.'
whenToSuggest: Candidate is earlier-stage and wants programs/projects not only jobs; Candidate is exploring multiple cause areas and wants a single 'opportunities surface'
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate gets overwhelmed by breadth (use one concrete program card instead)

goodFitIf: Earlier-stage and wants programs/projects not only jobs

firstSmallStep: Search 'AI safety' and save 3 opportunities that match your constraints/bandwidth.
nextStep: Apply to your top 1–2 opportunities or add them to your calendar for application deadlines.

title: MATS Program (Mentored AI Safety Training)
oneLiner: Intensive mentored research training; a serious step for people aiming at research entry.
whenToSuggest: Candidate is strongly research-leaning and wants a high-commitment path; Candidate is open to temporary relocation / intensive schedule
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is unsure about the field (start with A/B or SPAR); Relocation is a non-starter

goodFitIf: Open to temporary relocation / intensive schedule

firstSmallStep: Check the apply page and cohort details; sanity-check dates/relocation feasibility.
nextStep: If timing and location work, prepare your application materials.

title: Robert Miles — Intro to AI Safety, Remastered (YouTube)
oneLiner: A fast, widely-shared introduction that helps someone test whether AI safety is emotionally/intellectually compelling.
whenToSuggest: Candidate is curious but hasn't tested AI safety at all; Candidate prefers video and wants a quick 'do I care?' pass
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate already has strong familiarity and wants deeper field granularity

goodFitIf: Curious about AI safety but hasn't tested it yet
Wants a quick 'do I care?' pass

firstSmallStep: Watch the video and write 5 bullets: 'what risks felt real / what felt off / what questions I have.'
nextStep: Pick one of the questions you wrote and look for a resource that addresses it.
internalNotes: Good default when you want the resource to 'advocate better than you can.'

title: SPAR — Supervised Program for Alignment Research
oneLiner: Part-time, remote, mentored projects designed to produce work that contributes to AI alignment/safety—good 'measurable-good' project pathway.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants to do something real (not just learn); Candidate benefits from mentorship + defined projects; Candidate needs a push past impostor syndrome / 'I'm not ready'
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate can't realistically commit to the time window, even part-time

goodFitIf: Wants to do something real, not just learn
Benefits from mentorship and defined projects
Needs a push past impostor syndrome

firstSmallStep: Browse the current/most recent projects; shortlist 2–3 you'd genuinely apply to and write 2 lines each (interest + feasibility).
nextStep: Apply to the next cohort when applications open.

title: 80,000 Hours: Climate change problem profile
oneLiner: 80,000 Hours: Climate change problem profile
whenToSuggest: Use when it aligns with the focus area goals.
whenNotToSuggest: Skip if it does not match the person's constraints or interests.
firstSmallStep: Review the linked resources.
nextStep: Take the next action that feels most valuable.

title: 80,000 Hours — Job board
oneLiner: Filter for animal welfare or AI/data roles in adjacent orgs to explore career options.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants to see real job opportunities and org landscape; Candidate is motivated by concrete examples
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is very early and would spiral from job listings

goodFitIf: Wants to see real job opportunities and org landscape
Ready to bridge theory to action

firstSmallStep: Collect 8–12 roles → label role type (ML / research / ops / policy) → circle 3 roles + 2 repeating skill gaps.
nextStep: Research the top orgs from your list and identify skill gaps to address.

title: AI×Animals Fellowship (EA Opportunities) Effective Altruism+1
oneLiner: Structured 8-week remote program for careers at the intersection of AI and animal welfare.
whenToSuggest: Use when it aligns with the focus area goals.
whenNotToSuggest: Skip if it does not match the person's constraints or interests.
firstSmallStep: Review the linked resources.
nextStep: Take the next action that feels most valuable.

title: Animal Advocacy Careers — Job board
oneLiner: Search for data/tech roles; also helps you learn org landscape in animal advocacy.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants field-specific jobs in animal advocacy; Candidate is looking for data/tech roles
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate gets overwhelmed browsing listings

goodFitIf: Wants field-specific jobs in animal advocacy

firstSmallStep: Search for data/tech roles and save 8–12 interesting positions.
nextStep: Apply to roles that match your skills or start building identified skill gaps.

title: Animal Charity Evaluators — The impacts of AI on animal advocacy
oneLiner: High-level map of where AI can help or harm animal advocacy; a good first 'upsides + risks' framing.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants a quick map and a balanced view (opportunities + failure modes); Candidate is unsure whether 'AI × animals' is a real thing vs hype
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate wants concrete examples first (use RP human–wildlife conflict piece)

goodFitIf: Wants a quick map and balanced view
Unsure whether AI × animals is real vs hype
Values understanding both opportunities and risks

firstSmallStep: Read and note 3 use-cases + 3 failure modes.
nextStep: Pick one use-case that excited you and research orgs working on it.

title: Charity Entrepreneurship Incubation Program
oneLiner: ## Resources / links - https://80000hours.org/problem-profiles/health-in-poor-countries/ - https://www.charityentrepreneurship.com/ -…
whenToSuggest: Use when it aligns with the focus area goals.
whenNotToSuggest: Skip if it does not match the person's constraints or interests.
firstSmallStep: Review the linked resources.
nextStep: Take the next action that feels most valuable.

title: EA Opportunities — Browse AI × Animals / Animal Welfare / AI programs
oneLiner: Fellowships, programs, and projects that aren't just jobs—good for entry ramps.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants programs/fellowships/projects rather than traditional jobs; Candidate is earlier-stage and exploring
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate gets overwhelmed by broad lists (pick one specific program instead)
firstSmallStep: Search for AI × animals opportunities and save 3 that match your constraints/timeline.
nextStep: Apply to or bookmark your top opportunities.

title: Faunalytics — AI and Animal Advocacy
oneLiner: 'How advocates already use AI' and what adoption looks like—useful for reality-checking.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants a practical 'what's happening now in the field?'; Candidate is interested in tooling, workflows, comms, research support
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate wants deep technical + strategic analysis rather than usage patterns (use RP series)

goodFitIf: Wants a practical 'what's happening now in the field?'
Interested in tooling, workflows, comms, research support

firstSmallStep: Extract 5 adoption bottlenecks and 3 'high-value' AI tasks advocates could use.
nextStep: Identify one bottleneck you could help address with your skills.

title: Faunalytics — Volunteer
oneLiner: Research tooling / analysis contributions that directly support animal advocates.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants hands-on impact in the research tooling / analysis lane; Candidate likes producing outputs that real advocates will use
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate can't commit to any deadlines right now

goodFitIf: Wants hands-on impact in research tooling / analysis
Likes producing outputs for real advocates

firstSmallStep: Review volunteer options and draft a 3–5 sentence pitch: skills + a deliverable you can finish in 2–4 weeks.
nextStep: Submit your volunteer application.

title: Felidae Conservation Fund — Volunteer AI/ML specialist
oneLiner: Explicit volunteer role processing camera imagery for animal population research with real use.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants a concrete, externally useful project (measurable-good Experiment C); Candidate has AI/ML skills and wants to apply them to animals
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate can't sustain even part-time commitments right now

goodFitIf: Wants a concrete, externally useful project
Has AI/ML skills and wants to apply them to animals

firstSmallStep: Review the volunteer page and draft a message highlighting your ML skills and availability.
nextStep: Submit your volunteer application.

title: Futurekind AI Fellowship (EA Opportunities / Electric Sheep) Effective Altruism+2Electric Sheep+2
oneLiner: 12-week program to build skills and projects around AI for animal protection / environmental impact.
whenToSuggest: Use when it aligns with the focus area goals.
whenNotToSuggest: Skip if it does not match the person's constraints or interests.
firstSmallStep: Review the linked resources.
nextStep: Take the next action that feels most valuable.

title: Org-facing scoping note (AI × animals) — deliverable for an org/funder
oneLiner: A small research artifact meant to be used (shared with an org/funder), not a personal exercise.
whenToSuggest: Use when it aligns with the focus area goals.
whenNotToSuggest: Skip if it does not match the person's constraints or interests.
firstSmallStep: Review the linked resources.
nextStep: Take the next action that feels most valuable.

title: Rethink Priorities — AI for human–wildlife conflict mitigations
oneLiner: Concrete examples of 'AI-for-animals' in the real world; good for making it feel tangible.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants examples and mechanisms (not just 'AI will change everything'); Candidate is pulled toward wild animals / conservation-adjacent routes
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is primarily interested in farmed animals / food systems (use aquatic series)

goodFitIf: Pulled toward wild animals / conservation-adjacent routes

firstSmallStep: Pick one mitigation example and write a 1-page: 'how AI could help + what could go wrong + what evidence would change my mind.'
nextStep: Explore organizations working on human–wildlife conflict to learn about their approach.

title: Rethink Priorities — How AI is affecting farmed aquatic animals (series)
oneLiner: Deep 'EA research-y' analysis of innovation → deployment → welfare impacts in aquaculture.
whenToSuggest: Candidate likes research depth and wants to understand mechanisms and intervention hooks; Candidate is interested in farmed animals / food systems + technology
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate needs a structured cohort and peers rather than self-study (use fellowships)

goodFitIf: Likes research depth and wants to understand mechanisms
Interested in farmed animals / food systems + technology

nextStep: Pick one intervention hook and research orgs working on that approach.

title: Terra.do fellowship

title: 80,000 Hours — Factory farming problem profile
oneLiner: Canonical EA-style overview of why farmed animal welfare matters and what levers exist.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants a rigorous overview and 'why this matters'; Candidate likes reading and structured argumentation
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate already knows the basics and wants concrete next steps (use C/D)

goodFitIf: Wants a rigorous overview and 'why this matters'
New to the EA framing of animal welfare

internalNotes: Good 'anchor reading' if they want the EA framing.

title: 80,000 Hours — Job board
oneLiner: EA-filtered job board; good second lens for ops/policy/management roles relevant to animal orgs.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants broader EA options, or is considering adjacent roles supporting animals; Candidate wants a second job-board lens
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is early and would spiral from job listings
firstSmallStep: Same scan method; then pick 1 role type to test via a conversation or volunteer task.
nextStep: Apply for roles that match your skills or start building identified skill gaps.

title: 80,000 Hours Podcast — Lewis Bollard on factory farm advocacy gains
oneLiner: Practitioner 'field texture' for understanding what progress looks like and why tactics work.
whenToSuggest: Candidate learns best from interviews; Candidate wants realism about advocacy and strategy
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate tends to over-consume content instead of acting (use C or D)

goodFitIf: Wants realism about advocacy and strategy

firstSmallStep: Listen to the first ~30 minutes and extract 3 real-world constraints + 2 high-leverage roles.
nextStep: Research one of the high-leverage roles you identified.

title: 80,000 Hours — Wild animal welfare problem profile
oneLiner: Canonical EA overview for people pulled toward wild-animal suffering specifically.
whenToSuggest: Candidate is more interested in wild animals than farmed animals; Candidate is curious about 'less intuitive' intervention space
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is overwhelmed; start with factory farming or the video first

goodFitIf: More interested in wild animals than farmed animals

firstSmallStep: Skim + note 3 intervention angles and whether each feels motivating or alienating.
nextStep: If motivated, explore Wild Animal Initiative or other orgs in this space.

title: Animal Advocacy Careers — Animal volunteer opportunities
oneLiner: A curated way to find volunteer roles where your work is directly used by real orgs.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants hands-on impact now but doesn't know which orgs exist; Candidate needs a push from 'theory' to 'concrete help'
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate isn't ready to commit to anything ongoing (start with A/D)

Needs a push from 'theory' to 'concrete help'

title: Animal Advocacy Careers — Career advising
oneLiner: Tailored guidance for navigating roles/orgs; great when someone feels stuck or uncertain.
whenToSuggest: Candidate is motivated but confused about fit/path; Candidate wants personal guidance/accountability
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is progressing well self-directed and doesn't want advising
firstSmallStep: Book a call and prepare 2–3 specific questions about your path.
nextStep: Follow through on the action items from your advising call.

title: Animal Advocacy Careers — Introduction to Animal Advocacy Online Course
oneLiner: A structured course that maps the field and career options with more granularity.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants structured learning and a map of roles/orgs; Candidate is interested but still fuzzy on 'where I fit'

Interested but still fuzzy on 'where I fit'

title: Animal Advocacy Careers — Job board

title: Animal Charity Evaluators — Recommended Charities & Funds

title: Jacy Reese — Intro to effective animal advocacy (EAGxBerkeley talk)
oneLiner: A fast, approachable 'field picture' overview that tests interest and gives a first map.

title: 80,000 Hours — Biorisk research, strategy and policy career review

title: Project Drawdown — Climate Solutions 101 (playlist)
oneLiner: Clear, concrete 'what are solutions categories?' explainer; good for candidates who need video intuition fast.
whenToSuggest: Candidate prefers YouTube learning and wants a practical solutions map; Candidate is early and needs an accessible entry point
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is trying to optimize for EA-prioritized levers only (then keep to Probably Good / 80k and use Drawdown purely as intuition-building)

goodFitIf: Early and needs an accessible entry point

firstSmallStep: Watch 1 episode that matches their curiosity and write 5 bullets: 'what lever this is + what seems hard/neglected.'
nextStep: Pick 1 solution category that excited you and research who's doing the best work in that space.

title: Project — Giving drive informed by Giving Green
oneLiner: A measurable-good project for action-first candidates: $ influenced / donated toward vetted opportunities.
whenToSuggest: Candidate needs action to stay motivated or wants quick proof-of-fit; Candidate is comfortable doing a small outreach or workplace match
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is uncomfortable asking others (then suggest direct giving or job-board scanning)

goodFitIf: Needs action to stay motivated or wants quick proof-of-fit
Comfortable doing a small outreach or workplace match

firstSmallStep: Draft one short message + send to 5–10 people with a clear donation endpoint and a small target.
nextStep: Track donations raised and share progress with the community.

title: Terra.do — Climate Change: Learning for Action (12-week)
oneLiner: Structured 'map the space + find your role' container; good for people who want guided exploration.
whenToSuggest: Candidate likes cohorts and structure; Candidate has bandwidth for a medium commitment exploration phase
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate needs immediate action and tends to over-learn (use Work on Climate or job boards)
firstSmallStep: Look at syllabus + next cohort timing and see if it fits their timeline.
nextStep: Apply for the next cohort if timing works.

title: Work on Climate — Starter Packs + community
oneLiner: A guided way to explore climate sub-areas and see where your skills could fit.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants 'map the space' without committing to a long course; Candidate is unsure which climate lane to test first
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate already has a specific lane and just needs next actions (use job board / volunteering / giving)

goodFitIf: Wants to map the space without a long course
Unsure which climate lane to test first
Wants to see where their skills could fit

firstSmallStep: Pick one Starter Pack and do the first 1–2 items.
nextStep: Complete the Starter Pack and identify 2–3 roles or orgs that match your skills.

title: Work on Climate — Volunteering
oneLiner: A structured way to get momentum via real volunteering across functions (including research/data analytics).
whenToSuggest: Candidate needs action early / wants proof-of-fit / wants a push; Candidate wants a community container to stay motivated
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is already overloaded and volunteering would add stress (then do a job-board scan first)

goodFitIf: Needs action early or wants proof-of-fit
Wants a community container to stay motivated

firstSmallStep: Read the volunteering page and identify 1–2 roles you could plausibly do; draft a 5-line 'how I can help' note.
nextStep: Submit your volunteer application and join the community Slack.

title: 80,000 Hours — Health in poor countries
oneLiner: Canonical EA-style overview of global health: why it matters and what high-leverage work looks like.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants an EA 'map + why + how to help'; Candidate likes structured reading
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate wants video first (use GiveWell/GWWC explainer or Singer talk)

goodFitIf: Wants an EA map + why + how to help
New to global health as a cause area

firstSmallStep: Skim intro + 'what can you do?' and write 5 bullets: 'most exciting levers / biggest uncertainties.'
nextStep: Pick 1–2 levers from your list and research specific orgs doing that work.

title: 80,000 Hours — Job board
oneLiner: EA-filtered job board; good for mapping orgs/role types and turning interest into a direction to test.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants 'what roles exist?' and recurring skill patterns
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate gets overwhelmed by job boards (start with A)

goodFitIf: Wants to know what roles exist
Ready to turn interest into action

firstSmallStep: Scan 8–12 roles → label role types → circle 3 roles + 2 skill gaps → convert into 1 direction + 1 next step.
nextStep: Start building skills to address your identified gaps.

title: AIM — Entrepreneurship orientation (video)
oneLiner: EA-endorsed 'taste test' for entrepreneurship: helps someone quickly see what entrepreneurship-for-impact could look like.
whenToSuggest: Candidate is open to entrepreneurship (for-profit or nonprofit), even as a 'maybe'; Candidate wants a low-cost way to test fit without committing to a program; Candidate is considering routes like 'start a project,' 'build a product,' or 'launch an org'
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate has clearly said they don't want entrepreneurship; Candidate is currently overloaded and even a small new direction would feel stressful

goodFitIf: Wants a low-cost way to test fit
Considering routes like 'start a project' or 'launch an org'

firstSmallStep: Watch and write 3 bullets: what part felt exciting / what part felt aversive or draining / one constraint that would block entrepreneurship for you right now
nextStep: If excited, explore Charity Entrepreneurship's incubation program.
internalNotes: This works well as the 'Experiment A' for entrepreneurship because it can advocate better than you can and gives the candidate a shared reference point before you explore heavier options (e.g., Charity Entrepreneurship).

title: Charity Entrepreneurship — Incubation Program
oneLiner: EA-aligned, high-commitment path to founding a cost-effective charity with training, research, and network.
whenToSuggest: Candidate is genuinely excited by founding; Candidate can handle an intensive period + in-person component
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is not open to relocation / high intensity

goodFitIf: Can handle an intensive period + in-person component

firstSmallStep: Take the short quiz and skim the application flow.
nextStep: Apply for the next cohort if it fits your situation.

title: GiveWell — Our Top Charities
oneLiner: Canonical evaluator for cost-effective global health giving; also a map of interventions that work now.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants concrete 'what works?'; Candidate likes evidence and cost-effectiveness
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate feels pressured by giving (present as optional)

goodFitIf: Ready to give or explore giving

firstSmallStep: Read top charities page; choose either Top Charities Fund or one charity.
nextStep: Make a donation or set up recurring giving.

title: GiveWell — Top Charities Fund
oneLiner: Low-friction 'default option' for giving to GiveWell's highest-priority funding needs.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants a default giving option without picking a single org
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate wants to choose the org themselves

goodFitIf: Doesn't want to pick a single org

firstSmallStep: Make a one-time donation (any amount) or set a small recurring donation.
nextStep: Share GiveWell recommendations with friends or colleagues.

title: Giving What We Can — Pledge Drive
oneLiner: Measurable-good community action: pledges taken / giving committed. Giving What We Can
whenToSuggest: Use when it aligns with the focus area goals.
whenNotToSuggest: Skip if it does not match the person's constraints or interests.
firstSmallStep: Review the linked resources.
nextStep: Take the next action that feels most valuable.

title: Giving What We Can — Pledge
oneLiner: A commitment mechanism for people who want giving to be a stable part of life.
whenToSuggest: Candidate explicitly likes commitment devices and is financially comfortable
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is stressed by commitments or finances are uncertain

goodFitIf: Wants giving to be a stable part of life

firstSmallStep: Read pledge options and decide whether a smaller % / trial pledge fits better.
nextStep: Take the pledge if it feels right, or start with the trial pledge.

title: Giving What We Can YouTube — GiveWell explainer
oneLiner: A short, EA-aligned explainer of the evidence mindset behind GiveWell-style giving.
whenToSuggest: Candidate is new to evidence-based charity evaluation; Candidate prefers video
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate already 'gets' the idea and wants action (use Giving cards or Project C)

goodFitIf: Wants to understand the evidence mindset

firstSmallStep: Watch and write 3 bullets: 'what convinced me / what didn't / one question I want to investigate.'
nextStep: Explore GiveWell's top charities list with your new understanding.

title: GWWC — Global Health and Wellbeing Fund
oneLiner: Pooled giving allocated periodically using evaluator input (explicitly consults GiveWell).
whenToSuggest: Candidate likes pooled funds and evaluator-guided allocation
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate wants to pick specific charities
firstSmallStep: Donate once (even small) and see if it feels satisfying.
nextStep: Set up recurring donations if giving feels good.

title: Small donation drive → GiveWell Top Charities / Top Charities Fund
oneLiner: Measurable-good project: money moved to highly cost-effective programs.
whenToSuggest: Candidate needs action to stay motivated / wants proof-of-fit fast; Candidate is donation-positive and can do small outreach
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is very uncomfortable asking others for money

goodFitIf: Needs action to stay motivated or wants proof-of-fit
Donation-positive and can do small outreach

firstSmallStep: Draft one short message and send to 5–10 people with a clear donation endpoint.
nextStep: Track donations raised and share your results.

title: The Life You Can Save — Best Charities
oneLiner: EA-adjacent, evidence-backed recommended charity list with accessible explanations.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants an approachable curated list and narratives
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate wants strictly 'GiveWell-only' style
firstSmallStep: Pick one charity and read its 'why recommended' page.
nextStep: Make a donation or explore the charity further.

title: The Life You Can Save — Peter Singer TED talk
oneLiner: A values-first, EA-adjacent intro to 'why and how to give' for people who resonate more with moral framing.
whenToSuggest: Candidate is values-motivated and wants the 'why care?' framing; Candidate is new to effective giving
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate wants concrete 'what's effective?' evidence details (use GiveWell)

goodFitIf: Values-motivated and wants the 'why care?' framing

firstSmallStep: Watch and write: '1 thing I agree with / 1 thing I'm unsure about / 1 action this suggests.'
nextStep: Explore The Life You Can Save's best charities list.

title: Preventing an AI-related catastrophe (80,000 Hours)
oneLiner: The big strategic picture: why AI risk matters and what key interventions look like.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants the '10,000 foot view' before diving into technical details.
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is already familiar with the basic arguments.
firstSmallStep: Read the summary and the 'What you can do' section.
nextStep: Pick one intervention path that appeals to you to explore further.

title: Distill a Paper
oneLiner: Read one seminal paper (e.g. Constitutional AI or RLHF) and write a 1-page plain-English summary.
whenToSuggest: Candidate learns by explaining; Candidate wants to test their technical comprehension.
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate has zero technical background (start with videos instead).
firstSmallStep: Pick a paper (e.g. form Anthropic/DeepMind safety teams) and set a 2-hour timer to read and summarize.
nextStep: Share your summary with a friend or on a forum.

title: The 'Jailbreak' Test (Red Teaming)
oneLiner: Use a red-teaming interface to try and bypass safety guardrails. Understand *how* they fail.
whenToSuggest: Candidate likes 'breaking things'; Candidate is interested in safety engineering/security.
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate is looking for high-level strategy.
firstSmallStep: Try a game like Gandalf.lakera.ai or just try to jailbreak ChatGPT to say something it shouldn't.
nextStep: Read a paper on 'Adversarial Attacks' to understand the theory behind your jailbreak.

title: The 'Donation Pitch'
oneLiner: Pick a recommendation from Animal Charity Evaluators and write a 1-page brief on *why* it's effective.
whenToSuggest: Candidate wants to test their ability to analyze intervention effectiveness; Candidate likes writing/communication.
whenNotToSuggest: Candidate just wants to volunteer hands-on.
firstSmallStep: Read the 'Top Charities' page on Animal Charity Evaluators and pick one to analyze.
nextStep: Draft your 1-page brief and share it with a friend who isn't in EA.
